text:
CHRIS MOODY: We're here
in Baltimore, Maryland

for the NAACP annual
convention, the first meeting

they're having under
the Trump presidency.

ERIC HOLDER: Speak
up, don't be afraid.

Don't worry about being
the subject of a tweet.

CHRIS MOODY: Eric Holder spoke
today at the NAACP convention.
He just finished up.
Shaking a lot of hands.
Mr. Holder, Chris Moody, CNN.
Can we walk and talk?
Are you up for an interview?

What impact has
Trump had on activism
in communities of color?

ERIC HOLDER: Well, I think it's
probably galvanized people.

I think people feel that
there's the need to be active,

there's a need to be
involved, there's a need

to have their voices heard,
in opposition of some

of the policies of the
president and people

in the administration
have been pushing.

So I'm actually
kind of heartened

to see the numbers of
people, not only in minority

communities, but really
around the country,

people who are
expressing their views
and trying to shape policy.

CHRIS MOODY: Some of the biggest
names in Democratic politics
are here at the convention.
SEN.

KAMALA HARRIS: I think all
communities have been activated

and inspired to have their
voices heard, because they

feel their voices have not been
heard in this administration.
And I find it very exciting.

And I'm finding also
that it's people

of every generation,
of every gender,

of every geographic
area in our country.

And so that is certainly
a silver lining
to what's been going on.

CHRIS MOODY: So there's
a group of people

following Bernie Sanders
to the NAACP convention.

He's got a panel here with
a couple other lawmakers.
- He's very down to earth.
He has a very even track record.
He's been with the struggle.

TAVIAN MOORE: I wanted
to get a picture with him

to show my friends
and family back home.

I don't know, the work that
we're doing is important,

and I don't know,
it means a lot.

- The NAACP is the
oldest civil rights
organization in the country.

And they're trying to
figure out how they remain
relevant into the 21st century.

REV. KAJI S. DOUSA:
A very important

historic organization,
where a lot of people

are wondering, like,
what's their work now.

And I think the NAACP itself
is wondering that as well.

DERRICK JOHNSON:
One of the things

that people must understand,
that social justice
is not a competition.

We applaud all the young
people who get engaged.

Is it important that
we have more voices?

We are one vehicle that
people can plug into.

There are many other
vehicles, as there should be.

There have always
been other vehicles.

NAACP, our mission
is very clear.

We will continue to chart a
course based on that mission.

CHRIS MOODY: One person
noticeably absent,

the President of
the United States.

M. REESE EVERSON: We do
not have what we believe
is an ally in the White House.

We don't believe that we have
someone who is concerned,

unfortunately, for,
the truth of the matter

is, African-Americans
are not at the top
of anyone's political agenda.

LELAND MELVIN: I walked in
here today to the NAACP,

and I think, there's
a lot of people

that are talking
about things that they
can do in their communities.

There's something
that has to change.

And I know there's a groundswell
of activism and people
that are just fed up.

B.R. STINSON: President
Trump, and a lot

of people that are
for him, are just

ill-informed about the
African-American community.
And I believe they mean well.

But perception is
100% of reality.

And at this point,
his perception

of the African-American
community is just unfair.

CHRIS MOODY: How has
Donald Trump's presidency
changed activism in your mind?
Or maybe changed priorities?

M. REESE EVERSON: Our civil
rights, if they're not

enforced, if our children are
not safe in our communities,

if our young people are gunned
down, if our men are killed,
those things actually matter.

And so I think right now, you
know, yes, jobs are critical,

education is critical,
but safety is critical,
humanity is critical.

And those are the things
that we have to make sure
that we don't lose sight of.
